articles.headline: Wiretaps of Berlusconi’s Teenage Friend Emerge
articles.snippet: A nightclub dancer said she asked Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy for $6.7 million to keep quiet.
articles.abstract: A nightclub dancer said she asked Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy for $6.7 million to keep quiet.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME  A tabloid tidal wave washed over Italy on Tuesday as newspapers published eye-popping wiretapped conversations from a nightclub dancer who said she had dallied with Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi as a minor, but whether it would sweep the wily prime minister out to sea was still anyone’s guess.

articles.headline: Obama Asks for Review of Rules Stifling Jobs
articles.snippet: The order by the president was a signal to businesses that he wants to work more closely on job creation, though its immediate effect is likely to be mostly political.
articles.abstract: The order by the president was a signal to businesses that he wants to work more closely on job creation, though its immediate effect is likely to be mostly political.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday ordered “a governmentwide review” of federal regulations to root out those “that stifle job creation and make our economy less competitive,” but he exempted many agencies that most vex corporate America.

articles.headline: Apple’s Strong Holiday Season Lifts Revenue 70%
articles.snippet: The results far exceeded analysts’ bullish expectations. Even so, they were overshadowed by the decision by Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive, to take a medical leave.
articles.abstract: The results far exceeded analysts’ bullish expectations. Even so, they were overshadowed by the decision by Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive, to take a medical leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The holidays were really good to Apple.

articles.headline: Parenting by Gays More Common in the South, Census Shows
articles.snippet: Census Bureau demographers say new data shows that Jacksonville, Fla., is home to one of the biggest populations of gay parents in the country.
articles.abstract: Census Bureau demographers say new data shows that Jacksonville, Fla., is home to one of the biggest populations of gay parents in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Being gay in this Southern city was once a lonely existence. Most people kept their sexuality to themselves, and they were reminded of the dangers of being openly gay when a gay church was bombed in the 1980s. These days, there are eight churches that openly welcome gay worshipers. One even caters to couples with children.

articles.headline: Can Apple Find More Hits Without Its Tastemaker?
articles.snippet: Without Steven P. Jobs at the helm, can Apple continue its streak of innovation, particularly in a fast-moving industry?
articles.abstract: Without Steven P. Jobs at the helm, can Apple continue its streak of innovation, particularly in a fast-moving industry?
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly before the iPad tablet went on sale last year, Steven P. Jobs showed off Apple’s latest creation to a small group of journalists. One asked what consumer and market research Apple had done to guide the development of the new product.

articles.headline: U.S. Shifts Focus to Press China for Market Access
articles.snippet: American companies concerned with being beat by China-backed businesses have given President Obama support to pursue a tough approach with President Hu Jintao.
articles.abstract: American companies concerned with being beat by China-backed businesses have given President Obama support to pursue a tough approach with President Hu Jintao.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A year ago, the fight over how China’s cheap currency was hurting American companies in marketplaces at home and abroad was shaping up to be the epic battle between the world’s biggest power and its biggest economic rival.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Landler

articles.headline: A Look at Goldman, on the Brink of a Windfall
articles.snippet: Regulatory filings show the extent that the Wall Street firm concentrates power and money among its 475 partners.
articles.abstract: Regulatory filings show the extent that the Wall Street firm concentrates power and money among its 475 partners.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs executives have long been among the most richly paid on Wall Street in the best of times. They are now poised to reap a windfall that was sown in the dark days of the financial crisis in 2008.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Banks’ Underlying Problem Is Revenue
articles.snippet: Bank earnings since the peak of the financial crisis have been exaggerated to a large degree, in both directions, by the shuffling of reserves money.
articles.abstract: Bank earnings since the peak of the financial crisis have been exaggerated to a large degree, in both directions, by the shuffling of reserves money.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s banks are posting runaway profits for 2010, in a drastic reversal from 2009, when the prospect of widespread loan defaults forced them to set aside billions of dollars to cover losses.

articles.headline: In Wreckage of Lost Jobs, Lost Power
articles.snippet: The jobless rate is higher in the United States than in Britain, Germany, Japan or Russia, a new study found, pointing to American employers’ unusual degree of power.
articles.abstract: The jobless rate is higher in the United States than in Britain, Germany, Japan or Russia, a new study found, pointing to American employers’ unusual degree of power.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alone among the world’s economic powers, the United States is suffering through a deep jobs slump that can’t be explained by the rest of the economy’s performance.
